columns.text: In this exercise, we are given a bond quote from a newspaper, and we need to calculate the current yield and the yield to maturity.

Let's start by explaining what is current yield and how it is calculated. The current yield is the annual return an investor would earn if he purchased the bond. It is equal to the annual coupon payment divided by the current market price of the bond: $$ \begin{aligned} \text{Current Yield} = \frac{\text{Annual Coupon }}{\text{Current Market Price}} \tag{1} \end{aligned}$$ Hence, to calculate the current yield we need to first calculate the annual coupon payment and the current market price of the bond.

We calculate the current market price as follows: $$\text{Current Market Price} = \text{Last Price} \cdot \text{Face value}$$ Where the last price is expressed as a percentage of the face value. Given the face value of $2,000 and the last traded price of 108.96%, the current market price is: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Current Market Price} &= \text{Coupon rate} \cdot \text{Face value}\\[10pt] &=108.96\% \cdot \$2,000 \\[10pt] &=1.0896 \cdot \$2,000 \\[10pt] &= \$2,179.2\tag {3} \\ \end{aligned}$$ â€‹

Let's overview all the information we have on this bond before calculating the yield to maturity. 1. The coupon is paid annually. Hence, the number of compounding periods will equal the number of years left until maturity. The bond matures in 2034, and we bought the bond in 2018. Hence the number of compounding periods is 16 (2034 - 2018). 2. The face value is given, and it is $2,000. 3. We have calculated the values of coupon payments and the current market price, which are $114 and $2,179,2, respectively. To calculate the yield to maturity for this bond, input the above values into the formula: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Yield to maturity} &= \frac{ \$114 + \frac{\$2,000 - \$2,179.2}{16} }{\frac{\$2,000- \$2,179.2}{2}} \\[10pt] &= \frac{\$102.8}{\$2,089.6} \\[10pt] &= 0.04919\\[10pt] &= \boxed{4.919\%} \end{aligned}
